Metadata: Liquefaction susceptibility of sand reinforced with geotextiles
"In-situ Soil and Rock Reinforcement," Proceedings of the International Conference, Paris, France, October 9-11, 1984.

This paper describes the preliminary results of a research program on the dynamic behavior of saturated sand with fabric and fiber inclusions. Most of the existing man-made coastal and offshore fills have been constructed by dumping sand under water without compaction; such fills are usually loose and prone to liquefaction. Inclusion of geotextiles in the form of fabric in the fill can improve its resistance. The liquefaction susceptibility as a function of soil density, type and amount of geotextile inclusions, method of compaction, and confining pressure was investigated.
